Q: Problems when updating a list A:

The issue occurs because you are using list.extend().
The extend() method iterates over its argument and adds each element individually. Since a string is an iterable, Python treats "lopez" as a sequence of characters and adds each letter separately.

Example:

lista.extend("lopez")
# Result: ['Juan', 'Pedro', 'Pablo', 'l', 'o', 'p', 'e', 'z']

If your intention is to add the entire name as a single element, you should use one of the following approaches:

✅ Recommended Solution

lista.append(registronom)

✅ Alternative (if you want to keep using extend)

lista.extend([registronom])

Explanation:

  • append() adds one item to the list

  • extend() adds multiple items from an iterable

In this case, append() is clearer, safer, and more readable.
Using extend() with strings often leads to unintended behavior, as seen here.

Out of curiosity, is there a specific reason you preferred extend() over append() in this scenario?

Q: How-to perform a simple AWS/EC2 rest API call with Curl A:

The AWS API requests are unfortunately not straight forward to implement in curl. You are at least missing the canonical request that looks like that (from the example from the docs):

/
Action=ListUsers&Version=2010-05-08
content-type:application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8
host:iam.amazonaws.com
x-amz-date:20150830T123600Z

content-type;host;x-amz-date
e3b0c44298fc1c149afbf4c8996fb92427ae41e4649b934ca495991b7852b855

I recently started a litte project at https://github.com/sengaya/aws-micro-cli that implements some basic API calls of s3 and sts. While it does not support ec2 at this point you can look at the code or run something like this to get the final curl output as well as the steps to craft the request:

AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=foo AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=bar aws-micro s3 ls

Q: create database in server(truenas scale) A:

TrueNAS SCALE now natively supports Docker, starting from the 24.10 "Electric Eel" update.

This transition from Kubernetes makes running containers much lighter and more straightforward.

You can easily deploy a PostgreSQL container by using the "Custom App" feature in the Apps portal. Simply provide the PostgreSQL image name and define your environment variables, or use a Docker Compose file for more control. It is a highly efficient way to manage your database alongside your ZFS storage.

Youtube: A Better Way to Run Docker Apps on TrueNAS

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gPL7_tzsJO8

Q: Swift Package Manager: dependency iOS version A:

On my machine, adding the platforms: parameter to the manifest solved it. For example:

let package = Package(
    name: "MyLibrary",
    platforms: [.iOS("13.0")],
    // ...
